messageBody:
Don't get me wrong I'm a big fan of JUnit and unit testing but...

...I do regularly have problems using components, which would not have
occurred if there had been clearly stated pre-conditions (admittedly these
components don't usually come with associated unit tests).
Are a collection of unit tests a clear statement of the contract? I'm not
convinced. I do agree that by rigourously using TFD you will end up with
classes/methods with sweet smelling contracts. However if we consider the
airline metaphor which is often used for DBC: when I'm booking a ticket
with an airline I like to know the conditions which are attached - I don't
merely want a list of previous passengers and how they got on.

Steven Hale, wm-data

> >Interesting to see that John Goodsen (private method thread) is using

anybody
> >else is doing this and how they are implementing DBC (iContract? JASS?
or

>
>JBR
>
>Test-Driven Development drives a programmer towards DBC on a test-by-test
>basis. As a result, although I don't use DBC tools, I believe I'm doing
DBC
>
>by simply writing the tests first. In a way, JUnit is my DBC tool.
>
>From: steven.hale@...
>
>I can see your point from a component manufacturer's point of view - I can
>test that I can fullfil my contract using JUnit.
>
>From a component user view point I'd still like to see a concise
>description of the prerequisites without having to dig into the component
>code or even the unit testing code...
>... though I realise I'm in danger of reopening the javadoc v unit test
>discussion :-)

Indeed. Not only that, as a component user, I find that Javadoc is
sufficient to my purpose most of the time. It is rare that I need the level

of detail that a class' contract gives me. When I do need it, I want it in
a
formal notation, since natural languages are ambiguous. At that point, Java

code is the preferred formal notation, since Java is the language I program

in the most. I'll accept Smalltalk and muddle through with Ruby. Any way
you
slice it, I wanna see code. The best code is self-verifying executing code.

Sounds like a JUnit test. :)
